siteMetadata.title: Conversations on agile technical practices and investments

markdownRemark.excerpt: what are criteria in researching communities what are nearby amenities, attractions? when was the houses were commonly built? what are the common building type‚Ä¶
markdownRemark.html:
what are criteria in researching communities

  • what are nearby amenities, attractions?

  • when was the houses were commonly built?

  • what are the common building type?

  • what are the zoning regulations? does zoning regulations allows more units per lot?

  • what is the population? what is the population growth?

  • what is the average income in the area?

  • what is the crime rate?

  • what are the rentals supply/demand in the communities?

  • what are the average rents?

  • is it A, B, C, D neighborhood?

  • what are the long-term potential appreciation compared to current returns and cashflow?

  • what is average house prices?

  • what real estate investment strategies could work for this neighborhood?

  • what‚Äôs the prompt for AI to get more information on the communities?

  • you‚Äôre an expert in realestate investing, give me detailed outline on the Britannia neighborhood in Edmonton with the following questions:
    • what are nearby amenities, attractions?
    • when was the houses were commonly built?
    • what are the common building type?
    • what are the zoning regulations? does zoning regulations allows more units per lot?
    • what is the population? what is the population growth?
    • what is the average income in the area?
    • what is the crime rate?
    • what are the rentals supply/demand in the communities?
    • what are the average rents?
    • is it A, B, C, D neighborhood?
    • what are the long-term potential appreciation compared to current returns and cashflow?
    • what is average house prices?
    • what real estate investment strategies could work for this neighborhood?
  • stay away from 5 blocks of 132 Ave (stay away from the train tracks)

Oliver

  • https://www.edmonton.ca/public-files/assets/document?path=Neighbourhoods/OliverDemographicProfile.pdf

Below is a real-estate investor‚Äìfocused outline for Oliver (Edmonton) ‚Äî now commonly branded as W√Æhkw√™nt√¥win (formerly ‚ÄúOliver‚Äù) in many city planning contexts.

1) Nearby amenities & attractions (why tenants like it)

Core ‚Äúrentability‚Äù driver: Downtown-adjacent, walkable, transit-rich.

  • Jasper Avenue corridor (109 St ‚Üí 124 St): Edmonton‚Äôs main street feel, restaurants, retail, services; ongoing streetscape work (‚ÄúImagine Jasper Avenue‚Äù) improves walkability/streetscape over time.
  • 124 Street / Brewery District: shops, groceries, cafes, plus infill/mid-rise energy (strong for young professionals).
  • River Valley access (nearby): quick access to trails/parks (a premium for downtown renters).
  • Downtown employment + post-secondary proximity: ideal for renters who want short commutes.
  • LRT / major transit: high share of transit and walk commuters shows the area‚Äôs mobility advantage (important for reducing tenant car-dependency). (City of Edmonton)

Investor takeaway: Oliver behaves like a ‚Äúlifestyle rental node‚Äù ‚Äî demand tends to be resilient even when the city adds supply.

2) When homes were commonly built (stock age & renovation risk)

Oliver is not a single-era subdivision; it‚Äôs a long-evolving inner-city neighbourhood.

  • Expect a large share of older concrete high-rises + 1960s‚Äì1980s apartment stock, plus newer infill and newer luxury rentals/condos scattered around Jasper Ave / key corridors.
  • Practical implication: big variance in condo fees, building envelope quality, special assessment risk (due diligence is everything in this neighbourhood type).

(No single ‚Äúbuilt year‚Äù dominates like a suburban community ‚Äî the asset-quality dispersion is the story.)

3) Common building types (what you‚Äôll actually buy)

2014 municipal census (still directionally useful for housing form mix) shows Oliver is overwhelmingly apartment-based:

  • Apartment (5+ stories): ~66%
  • Apartment (1‚Äì4 stories): ~30%
  • Single detached / row / duplex/fourplex: tiny shares (City of Edmonton)

Investor takeaway: Oliver is primarily a condo + purpose-built rental market, not a ‚Äúbuy a house and suite it‚Äù market (unless you‚Äôre very targeted on a few pockets).

4) Zoning & whether it allows more units per lot

Because Oliver is inner-city, zoning is typically more permissive than suburban areas, and the neighbourhood has historically been planned for medium/high density along key corridors.

What this usually means in practice:

  • Corridor + node sites (esp. Jasper Ave / major streets): often allow mid-rise / high-rise / mixed-use redevelopment.
  • Interior pockets: may still have smaller-scale residential zones, but even then, inner-city rules tend to allow more infill forms than many suburbs (subject to setbacks, height, FAR, parking rules, etc.).

Action step (how investors verify quickly):

  • Use the City‚Äôs zoning map ‚Üí confirm the exact parcel zoning and check allowable uses (multi-unit, mixed-use, etc.).
  • If you‚Äôre pursuing ‚Äúmore units per lot,‚Äù target parcels already designated for medium/high-density or mixed-use rather than trying to rezone a low-scale interior lot.

(I didn‚Äôt pull a parcel-by-parcel zoning breakdown in this pass; if you tell me a cross-street or a listing link, I can translate the exact zone into what you can build.)

5) Population & population growth (demand base)

  • 2019 Municipal Census population: 18,180 (City of Edmonton)
  • 2014 Municipal Census population: 19,135 (City of Edmonton)

Interpretation: Over that window, Oliver looks roughly flat to slightly down (not explosive growth). In inner-city areas, population can be sensitive to:

  • demolition/redevelopment timing,
  • temporary vacancy during major projects,
  • shifts between condo-ownership vs rental occupancy.

6) Average income in the area (tenant quality signal)

I wasn‚Äôt able to reliably extract a neighbourhood-specific ‚Äúaverage income‚Äù figure from a primary City/StatsCan table within the tool limits in this run, so I‚Äôm not going to guess.

What I can say confidently based on the housing mix:

  • With very high renter share and high apartment concentration (City of Edmonton), Oliver‚Äôs income profile is typically mixed (students/early-career renters + established professionals in higher-end towers).

If you want, I can produce an income estimate with citations by pulling the specific federal census neighbourhood table for W√Æhkw√™nt√¥win/Oliver in a follow-up.

7) Crime rate (risk, vacancy, and tenant-management reality)

You should assume Oliver has higher downtown-style incident levels than most suburban neighbourhoods.

Best source to quantify (by incident type and time window):

  • Edmonton Police Service Community Safety Data Portal / Neighbourhood Crime Mapping (Edmonton Police Service)
  • City safety dashboards exist as well (good for trends). (gis.edmonton.ca)

Investor takeaway: In Oliver, your edge comes from:

  • building/tenant screening systems,
  • solid property management,
  • choosing blocks/buildings with better micro-location.

8) Rental supply/demand dynamics (what drives cashflow)

Oliver is structurally renter-heavy:

  • Rented units ~62.6% (2014 municipal census) (City of Edmonton)

So demand is deep, but supply is also active (lots of competing buildings).

What this means for you:

  • Compete on unit quality, in-suite laundry, parking, pet policy, and building amenities.
  • Expect tenants to ‚Äúshop‚Äù hard: price sensitivity + lots of alternatives.

9) Average rents (neighbourhood + city context)

Neighbourhood snapshot (listings-based):

  • RentFaster Oliver 1-bedroom page shows many asking rents around the mid-$1,400s+ range (varies heavily by building age/amenities). (RentFaster.ca)

City benchmark (CMHC survey snapshot in a municipal highlights doc):

  • Edmonton City average rents (2024 survey snapshot): Bachelor ~$1,051; 1-bed ~$1,218; 2-bed ~$1,513; 3+ ~$1,695. (City of St. Albert)

Investor takeaway: Oliver often rents at/above city average for comparable bedroom counts, but competition is intense ‚Äî you win on ‚Äútotal package,‚Äù not just price.

10) Neighbourhood grade (A / B / C / D)

My investor-grade for Oliver/W√Æhkw√™nt√¥win: B- / C+ (depends heavily on micro-block + building).

Why not A:

  • Crime/incident risk higher than suburban family areas (management intensity). (communitysafetydataportal.edmontonpolice.ca)
  • Condo fee / special assessment risk can be meaningful in older towers.

Why not D:

  • Strong amenities, walkability, employment adjacency, and persistent renter demand.

11) Long-term appreciation potential vs current returns/cashflow

Typical pattern in dense inner-city condo-heavy areas:

  • Cashflow can work if you buy right (smaller units, good building, realistic fees, strong tenant profile).
  • Appreciation can lag single-family land-constrained neighbourhoods unless you‚Äôre positioned in a building/micro-location that benefits from corridor upgrades and reinvestment.

A real bullish driver to watch:

  • Public realm investment on Jasper Ave (streetscape, pedestrian upgrades) tends to support desirability over time.

Practical expectation: Oliver is often more of a yield + stability play than a ‚Äúhome-run appreciation‚Äù play (unless you‚Äôre doing redevelopment/infill where zoning supports it).

12) Average house prices (what you‚Äôll pay)

Because Oliver is mostly apartments/condos, ‚Äúaverage house price‚Äù can be misleading.

One neighbourhood market reference:

  • HonestDoor shows an Average ‚ÄúHonestDoor Price‚Äù for Oliver (Edmonton) ~ $758,794 (their blended stat across home types). (HonestDoor)

How investors should translate this:

  • Break your comps into (1) condos, (2) purpose-built rental opportunities, (3) rare small multifamily / land assemblies ‚Äî don‚Äôt use one blended ‚Äúaverage‚Äù to underwrite.

13) Strategies that can work well in Oliver (investor playbook)

A) ‚ÄúHigh-occupancy, low-drama‚Äù condo rentals (best for limited time)

  • Target concrete buildings with:

    • healthy reserve fund history,
    • stable condo fees (not artificially low),
    • no major known envelope/parking membrane issues,
    • strong rental demand features (laundry, parking, pet friendliness).

  • Underwrite with stress tests: condo fee increases + special assessment reserve.

B) ‚ÄúFurnished mid-term rental‚Äù (travel nurses / corporate / relocation)

  • Works best near:

    • hospitals, downtown offices, transit.

  • You‚Äôll need tighter operations (turnovers, furnishing, insurance, bylaws/condo rules).

C) Value-add on older units (cosmetic + layout)

  • Because there‚Äôs a lot of older stock, a clean renovation can beat competing listings.
  • Focus upgrades that actually move rent: flooring, lighting, kitchen refresh, in-suite laundry (if feasible), sound/privacy improvements.

D) Infill / redevelopment (only on the right parcels)

  • If you want ‚Äúmore units per lot,‚Äù your edge is:

    • buying sites already aligned with medium/high density or mixed-use intent,
    • assembling small lots,
    • riding corridor revitalization (Jasper Ave, etc.).

E) Portfolio role (how Oliver fits a bigger plan)

  • Oliver can be a ‚Äúcashflow anchor / renter-demand anchor‚Äù while you pursue appreciation-heavy plays elsewhere (single-family land value, suite strategies, etc.).

  • established homeowners, well-rounded
  • established shoppings centers,
  • good access to major roads.
  • still in good price point

Ellerslie

Here‚Äôs a comprehensive investor‚Äëstyle neighborhood outline for Ellerslie in southeast Edmonton, based on the latest publicly‚ÄØavailable data (~2019‚Äì2025):

‚úÖ 1. Nearby amenities & attractions

  • Several small parks and pathway networks throughout the community (City of Edmonton)
  • Nearby Summerside and Walker Park, local playgrounds, and the former Ellerslie Rugby Park (closed 2022) (Wikipedia)
  • Commercial nodes along Ellerslie Road and 91 Street provide grocery stores, banks, fast food, small restaurants, and proximity to South Edmonton and Windermere shopping areas (AreaVibes)

üèóÔ∏è 2. When houses were built & common building types

  • Community planned in early‚Äë2000s; rapid residential development followed, mostly completed by mid‚Äë2010s (City of Edmonton)
  • Building types: ~60‚Äì66% single‚Äëfamily detached; ~20% row/semi‚Äëdetached/duplex; ~12‚Äì15% townhouses; low‚Äërise apartments ~5‚Äì12% (Gimme-Shelter)

üìê 3. Zoning and density (units per lot)

  • Based on Edmonton‚Äôs Area Structure Plan and Neighbourhood Structure Plan, zoning supports low to medium density: R‚Äë1 (single detached), R‚Äë2/R‚Äë3 (semi, duplex) and R‚ÄØTH / R‚ÄØAD for townhouses/apartments in specific nodes.
  • Most lots are single‚Äëdetached; townhome/duplex zones allow multiple units per lot in designated blocks. Opportunities exist in re‚Äëzoning older lots for infill, but majority built-out under original zoning‚ÄØplan (City of Edmonton, Wikipedia)

üßç 4. Population & growth

  • 2012 municipal census: 5,566 residents, 5.7‚ÄØ% growth since 2009 (Wikipedia)
  • Broader Ellerslie area (including Orchards, Summerside) had ~8,400 residents by 2019 across ~3,000 dwellings (~2.49‚ÄØkm¬≤) (Gimme-Shelter)

üí∞ 5. Average income

  • Median household income ~C$106,400‚Äî~12% above Alberta average, and ~29% above national average (AreaVibes)

üö® 6. Crime rate

  • Overall crime ~11% lower than Edmonton average; raw rate ~5,695 per 100,000 people‚Äîthough Edmonton averages are high in national terms (AreaVibes)

üèòÔ∏è 7. Rental supply & demand

  • Current rental listings in Ellerslie (~19‚Äì25 active units across types); mix of duplexes, townhouses, condos, basement suites, some single‚Äëfamily rental houses (RentFaster.ca)
  • Demand seems modest but steady; many homeowners, but also families and professional renters nearby. Limited supply but data is partial.

üíµ 8. Average rents

According to RentFaster and Zumper:

  • Duplexes: avg ~$2,216‚ÄØ/mo (ranges ~$2,100‚Äì2,300)
  • Townhouses: avg ~$1,746‚ÄØ/mo (~1,525‚Äì1,850)
  • Condos/apartments: ~$1,573‚ÄØ/mo
  • Basements: ~$1,095‚Äì1,350 (~avg‚ÄØ$1,222)
  • Houses: ~$2,275 for full single‚Äëfamily rental (RentFaster.ca)

üèôÔ∏è 9. A/B/C/D Neighborhood Grade

  • Livability score ~66/100 (‚ÄúGood‚Äù)
  • Amenities score D (few local amenities), crime grade D, cost of living A, employment A+, housing A, but schools D+ (AreaVibes)
  • Overall this suggests a B‚Äërange neighborhood: strong housing, income, safety; limited walkable retail/schools.

üìä 10. House prices & appreciation potential

  • Specific median sale price data not in public summary; market listed by some sources as ‚Äún/a‚Äù (AreaVibes)
  • Comparatively newer suburban southeast area, moderate‚Äëto‚Äëstrong long‚Äëterm appeal tied to Windermere expansion, proximity to Anthony Henday, growing population.
  • Likely price growth in line with Edmonton suburban avg (~3‚Äì5% annually), with upside via infill or densification.

üí° 11. Investment strategies

‚úÖ A. Value-add / infill

  • Acquire older single‚Äëfamily on standard lots and apply for rezoning/infill (duplex, townhome) to increase density and cashflow.

‚úÖ B. New-build rental or townhomes

  • Develop small multi‚Äëunit infill. New units in townhome form can command $1,700‚Äì2,200+/mo.

‚úÖ C. Long‚Äëterm hold (buy & hold single family)

  • With median income and low vacancy rates, rent well. Stable moderate cashflow if leveraged.

‚úÖ D. BRRRR strategy on basement suites

  • Purchase single-family, add legal basement rental suite; collect basement rent (~$1,200) while long-term tenants upstairs.

‚úÖ E. Multi-family rental block

  • Invest in or develop low-rise apartment units in designated zones near transit corridors or commercial nodes.

üìã Summary Table

Topic Snapshot
Population (2019 est) ~8,400
Growth rate (2009‚Äì12) ~5.7‚ÄØ%
Housing stock ~60% detached, ~20% semi/row, ~12‚Äì15% townhouse, 5‚Äì12% apartments
Avg rent (townhouse) ~$1,750‚ÄØ/mo
Median income ~$106,400/year
Crime ~11% under city avg
Neighborhood grade B overall
Zoning Low to mid density; infill possible
Investment fit Infill, small multi-unit, hold & rent, BRRRR

üîç Recommend next steps

  • Get updated MLS data for recent sold house prices (~2024‚Äì25).
  • Obtain City of Edmonton zoning maps and property-specific zoning to evaluate infill permissions.
  • Review transit access (future LRT plans) and commercial development pipeline in Ellerslie and Windermere.
  • Survey vacancy & rent listings over three months to validate demand.

Grovenor

Here‚Äôs a comprehensive investor‚Äëstyle overview of Grovenor, a mature neighbourhood in west Edmonton, based on up‚Äëto‚Äëdate data into mid‚Äë2025:

üèôÔ∏è 1. Nearby amenities & attractions

  • MacKinnon Ravine lies just south of Grovenor, offering direct access to walking and cycling trails leading into the North‚ÄØSaskatchewan River Valley Park system (City of Edmonton).
  • Commercial services and shops are concentrated along Stony Plain Road and 149‚ÄØStreet, including cafes, restaurants, small clinics and boutique retail (City of Edmonton).
  • Nearby major attractions include Telus World of Science, Heritage Amphitheatre, Earth Sciences Museum, Clare Drake Arena ‚Äî accessible within minutes to the east (AreaVibes).

üèóÔ∏è 2. Housing age & development timeline

  • Initial residential development began around 1907‚Äì1910, with many early homes built pre‚ÄëWWII, around 18% by 1945; most construction was completed by 1980 (Wikipedia).
  • Redevelopment and infill have continued in recent decades, especially along Stony Plain Road (City of Edmonton).

üè° 3. Common building types

  • Predominantly single‚Äëdetached homes (~88%), with duplexes (~9%) and row houses (~3%); almost 77% owner‚Äëoccupied, remainder rented (Wikipedia).

üìê 4. Zoning and density opportunities

  • As a mature area, Grovenor is zoned for low‚Äëdensity residential (single detached, duplex, low‚Äërise infill). Existing duplexes and low‚Äërise apartments reflect mid‚Äëcentury in‚Äëfill (City of Edmonton).
  • Rezoning older parcels for duplex or multi‚Äëunit infill is possible, especially where redevelopment is allowed under the City‚Äôs Mature Neighbourhood Overlay.

üë• 5. Population & growth

  • According to Edmonton‚Äôs municipal census: 2,362 residents in 2012, representing a 12% growth from 2009, at 2,567‚ÄØpeople/km¬≤ in a 0.92‚ÄØkm¬≤ area (Wikipedia).
  • More recent data (mid‚Äë2025) estimates population around 2,231‚Äîa slight decline or estimate variance; household mix: ~35% single persons, 58% families, 65% owners vs 35% renters (Wahi).

üí∞ 6. Average household income

  • Median household income around C$104,000, ~10% above Alberta average (AreaVibes).
  • Another source estimates average household income ~C$146,800, reflecting likely newer or higher‚Äëearning households as of mid‚Äë2025 (Wahi).

üö® 7. Crime rate

  • Estimated total crime rate ~5,049 per 100,000, around 20% higher than Canada average, but still ~20% below Alberta average (AreaVibes).
  • Violent crime slightly lower than national average; chance of any crime ~1 in 20 annually (AreaVibes).

üèòÔ∏è 8. Rental supply & demand

  • Active rental listings remain limited: only a handful of apartments, basement units and townhouse rentals visible (e.g. 4 on Zillow) (Zillow).
  • Demand seems steady for small units given proximity to the core and ravine access; limited rental stock supports moderate demand.

üíµ 9. Average rents

  • Zumper average rent overall ~C$1,465/month:

    • 1‚Äëbed: ~$1,094
    • 2‚Äëbed: ~$1,600
    • 3‚Äëbed: ~$2,299/month (Zumper - Apartments for Rent & Houses).

  • HonestDoor estimates average rent ~C$2,668 (likely including houses/condos) as of July‚ÄØ2025 (HonestDoor).

üèòÔ∏è 10. Neighborhood Grade (A/B/C/D)

  • Livability rated ~86/100, strong on amenities, housing, employment; crime gets D+, cost of living B, overall housing A‚Äë, schools and safety rated A+ by Areavibes also (AreaVibes).
  • Overall this positions Grovenor as a strong B‚Äëgrade to low‚ÄëA neighbourhood: established, mature, safe with slightly above average income and housing value.

üìà 11. Average house prices & appreciation potential

  • Recent median sale price in 2021‚Äì22: ~C$400,000 (e.g. ~1,000‚ÄØsq‚ÄØft bungalow built in 1955) with individual sales from ~C$250k to C$1.15M (Schmidt Realty Group).
  • HonestDoor 2025 average price ~C$553,000, down ~1.8% from previous month, with ~$428/sq‚ÄØft sale rate (HonestDoor).
  • Appreciation: Properties in Grovenor typically steady long‚Äëterm growth, buoyed by mature location, infill potential, and core‚Äëarea attraction; modest rental yields vs appreciation from price growth.

üß∞ 12. Investment strategies that fit Grovenor

‚úÖ A. Infill / Build-Down

  • Convert older single‚Äëfamily homes by adding legal basement suites or secondary units for rental income.

‚úÖ B. Duplex / Triplex redevelopment

  • Acquire aging homes and subdivide or redevelop into duplex or small muti‚Äëunit under mature neighbourhood guidelines‚Äîsubject to zoning and overlay approvals.

‚úÖ C. Buy‚Äëand‚Äëhold single-family

  • Higher‚Äëincome neighbourhood supports stable rental income (~C$2.6k for condos; lower for apartments). Good long‚Äëterm appreciation, modest cap rate.

‚úÖ D. Small-scale condos or townhomes

  • Target infill parcels or redevelopment along Stony Plain Road corridors for low‚Äërise multi‚Äëunit projects targeting professionals.

‚úÖ E. Renovate and flip

  • Due to mix of older dwellings, cosmetic renovation and modernization can yield returns, especially if resale targets >C$550k.

üìã Summary Table

Topic Snapshot
Population (2025 est.) ~2,200‚Äì2,400
Growth (2009‚Äì12) ~12%
Housing stock ~88% single-detached, ~9% duplex, ~3% row-houses
Median income $104‚ÄØk‚Äì146‚ÄØk
Crime ~5,049/100k (low‚Äëmoderate), ~1 in 20 chance
Avg rent ~$1,100‚Äì2,300 (depending on type)
Housing values (2025) avg ~$553k; median ~$400k (2021)
Livability grade B‚Äë to A‚Äë overall
Zoning Low-density; infill possible under mature overlay

üîç Recommended Next Steps

  1. Pull recent MLS sales (2023‚Äì25) for Grovenor for accurate median sale prices per dwelling type.
  2. Review City of Edmonton zoning maps, Mature Neighbourhood Overlay rules, and infill permitting processes.
  3. Pull Edmonton Police crime mapping for fine-grained trends in Grovenor (NextHome, City of Edmonton, Wikipedia, AreaVibes, Schmidt Realty Group, AreaVibes, Edmonton Police Service).
  4. Analyze rental market trends over the past 12 months from CMHC or rental platforms.

Belmead

Here‚Äôs a comprehensive investor-focused overview of Belmead, a mature west Edmonton neighbourhood, with detailed answers to your questions:

üèòÔ∏è 1. Nearby Amenities & Attractions

  • West Edmonton Mall, Canada‚Äôs largest mall, lies just east ‚Äî less than 5‚ÄØminutes away by car with major retail, entertainment, and restaurants nearby (Wikipedia).
  • Local parks, playgrounds, schools, and community league facilities are dispersed throughout the area, supporting family living (Wikipedia, City of Edmonton).
  • Easy access to Anthony Henday Drive (Highway 216) gives direct access to the Edmonton International Airport and southern parts of the city (Wikipedia).

üèóÔ∏è 2. Housing Age & Development Timeline

  • Development began in the 1960s (approx. 6.3% of units), followed by heavy growth in the 1970s (~60%) (Wikipedia).
  • Additional construction occurred through the 1980s (~19%) and 1990s (~13%), making it a largely mature residential area with most homes built by 1999 (Wikipedia).

üè° 3. Common Building Types

  • As per 2005 data: about 50% single‚Äëdetached houses, 36% row houses, 9‚Äì10% low-rise apartments, and ~5% duplex/triplex units (censusdocs.edmonton.ca).
  • Owner-occupancy stands at around 72%, with 28% rental units (Wikipedia).

üìê 4. Zoning & Density Potential

  • Planned under the Belmead Neighbourhood Structure Plan (1981 ASP) with emphasis on efficient higher density vs surroundings, especially clustering multi-unit structures near transit corridors (City of Edmonton).
  • Predominantly low to medium density zoning (single detached, row housing, low-rise apartments); potential exists for infill redevelopment or multi‚Äëunit conversions in specific zones, subject to City overlay rules.

üë• 5. Population & Growth

  • 2012 municipal census recorded 4,603 residents in 1.28‚ÄØkm¬≤ ‚Äî at ~3,596 per km¬≤, representing ~2.6% growth since 2009 (Wikipedia).
  • The 2019 estimate shows ~3,810 residents across ~1,450 dwellings (some variation in data sets) (Gimme-Shelter).
  • Broadly stable population, moderate turnover ‚Äî typical mobility with ~10% moving in last year, ~18% in past 3 years (BeechWoolger).

üí∞ 6. Average Household Income

  • Median household income ~C$83,500 (about 12% below Alberta average, slightly above national average) (AreaVibes).

üö® 7. Crime Rate

  • Overall crime rate 6,706 per 100,000 residents, approx. 5% higher than Edmonton average, and 59% above Canadian average (AreaVibes).
  • Personal risk estimated at 1 in 15 chance of being a victim annually (AreaVibes).

üèòÔ∏è 8. Rental Supply & Demand

  • Rental listings include a selection of apartments and row‚Äëhouses; Zumper lists about 25 active listings (mostly 2‚Äë3 bed units) (Zumper - Apartments for Rent & Houses).
  • Demand steady but moderate‚Äîsupportive of affordable workers/families rather than premium segments; rental supply adequate for this demographic.

üíµ 9. Average Rents

  • Average rent for 3-bedroom apartments about C$1,396/month (Zumper - Apartments for Rent & Houses).
  • Smaller units (1‚Äì2‚ÄØbed) likely range from C$1,000‚Äì1,300/month, consistent with broader west‚Äëend Edmonton pricing.

üèÖ 10. Neighborhood Grade

  • Livability score: 83/100 (considered exceptional) (HonestDoor, AreaVibes).
  • Housing described as ‚Äúvery affordable with above average appreciation potential‚Äù (AreaVibes).
  • However crime is a weakness, rated F-crime in Areavibes data. Cost of living is low (A), employment B, overall housing affordability good.
  • Grade: B‚Äërange ‚Äî affordable and family-oriented, but with elevated crime relative to city.

üè† 11. Average House Prices & Appreciation Potential

  • As of July‚ÄØ2025, 12 active listings, average asking price ~C$383,700, mean listing price ~$283/sq‚ÄØft across ~1,271‚ÄØsq‚ÄØft homes (AreaVibes, edmontonhomes.ca).
  • Sale prices span ~C$110k to $700k, reflecting mix of condos, row-houses and detached homes (edmontonhomes.ca).
  • Historically appreciation is steady and moderate, with higher potential upside via row-house or townhouse conversions.
  • Good cash flow potential due to lower purchase prices and affordable rents yielding reasonable cap rates for investors.

üß∞ 12. Investment Strategies

A. Buy‚Äëand‚ÄëHold Detached or Row-Houses

  • Affordable entry (mid‚Äë$300k), stable rental return (approx. $1,300‚Äì1,400/mo for 3-bed units) offers moderately positive cash flow.

B. BRRRR or Legal Basement Suites

  • Buying a detached or row‚Äêhome, renovating and adding a legal basement suite can boost rental income and value.

C. Small Multi‚Äëunit or Townhouse Redevelopment

  • Under NSP and zoning, possible to acquire older units and redevelop into row housing or low-rise townhouses to increase density and yield.

D. Entry-level Rentals Targeting Young Families/Professionals

  • With average income below city average, lower‚Äëcost 2‚Äë3 bedroom rentals appeal to middle-income households, students, and entry workers.

Kilkenny

Here‚Äôs an investor‚Äëfocused profile of Kilkenny, a mature northeast Edmonton neighbourhood, updated through mid‚Äë2025:

üèôÔ∏è 1. Nearby Amenities & Attractions

  • Serviced by Londonderry Mall just south in Kildare, plus North Town Centre & Northgate Centre nearby. Also on-site Londonderry Fitness & Leisure Centre, playfields, and athletic grounds within Kilkenny (Wikipedia).
  • Parks include Kilkenny Park, G. Edmund Kelly Park, spray park, and well-connected school grounds (AreaVibes).

üèóÔ∏è 2. Housing Age & Development Timeline

  • Development largely occurred in the 1960s (‚âà51%) and 1970s (‚âà23%), with most build-out completed by 1990 (Wikipedia, City of Edmonton).

üè° 3. Common Building Types

  • Of all dwellings: ~60% single‚Äëdetached houses, ~30% low-rise apartments, and ~10% row houses; duplexes/triplexes negligible (<1%) (Wikipedia).
  • Owner‚Äëoccupancy ~62%, rental ~38% (Wikipedia).

üìê 4. Zoning & Density Potential

  • Zoned for low to medium density residential. Dominated by single-family zoning, with pockets of row‚Äëhousing and low‚Äërise apartments.
  • Some potential exists for infill or small multi-unit redevelopments within the mature Londonderry overlay‚Äîbut mass densification is limited without rezoning (Wikipedia).

üë• 5. Population & Growth

  • 2012 municipal census: 5,715 residents in ~1.75‚ÄØkm¬≤, density 3,266/km¬≤. Population declined slightly (‚Äì1.9%) from 2009 (Wikipedia).
  • More recent estimates: ~4,500 residents in ~1,500 homes (Gimme Shelter) (Gimme-Shelter).
  • Growth is flat to moderate; mobility rates moderate: ~13% moved within 12‚ÄØmonths and ~20% within 1‚Äì3‚ÄØyears (2005 data) (Wikipedia).

üí∞ 6. Average Household Income

  • Median household income around C$72,571, ~12% below Canada average and ~23% below Alberta average (AreaVibes).

üö® 7. Crime Rate

  • Livability score: 67/100 (‚ÄúGood‚Äù).
  • Crime rate: 7,661 per 100,000, about 20% higher than Edmonton average, 81% above national average. Risk of victimization: 1 in 14 annually (AreaVibes).

üèòÔ∏è 8. Rental Supply & Demand

  • Rental listings modest: Zillow shows only 3 current apartment listings, rents between C$1,339‚Äì1,779 (Zillow).
  • Zumper lists ~25 house rentals across adjacent areas, though few directly in Kilkenny; typical rents ~C$1,300‚Äì1,400 (Zumper - Apartments for Rent & Houses).

üíµ 9. Average Rents

  • Small apartments (1‚ÄØbd) average ~C$1,340‚Äì1,360/month; larger units (3‚ÄØbd) around C$1,780/month (Zillow, Zumper - Apartments for Rent & Houses).
  • Little data on row houses, but they are likely similar or slightly more.

üèÖ 10. Neighborhood Grade

  • Livability 67/100; amenities C, employment C+, cost of living A+, housing B+; crime rated F in Areavibes grading (AreaVibes).
  • Overall, Kilkenny is a C‚Äë or lower B‚Äëgrade area: affordable housing but higher crime and average incomes.

üìà 11. Average House Prices & Appreciation Potential

  • MLS listings mid‚Äë2025 show townhomes ~C$220k, single‚Äëfamily homes C$399‚Äì435k; apartments as low as C$78‚Äì81k (Zillow, edmontonrealestate.pro).
  • Overall values remain entry-level relative to Edmonton norm; neighborhood offers modest appreciation but limited upside unless broader area revitalization occurs.

üß∞ 12. Investment Strategies

‚úÖ A. Buy‚Äëand‚ÄëHold Entry-Level Rentals

  • Low acquisition costs (~C$400k) and rents ~C$1,300‚Äì1,780/mo offer moderate positive cash flow even with elevated risk from crime; good for affordable market tenants.

‚úÖ B. BRRRR with Basement Suites

  • Legal suites in bungalows can raise total rent income, improving return in lower-priced homes.

‚úÖ C. Small Infill or Row-House Redevelopment

  • Opportunities where row housing allowed; limited scale but could densify pockets within zoning provisions.

‚úÖ D. Acquire & Renovate Value Properties

  • Cosmetic upgrades or modest renovation of aging apartments or townhomes could extract value for resale or rent bump.

Belvedere

Here‚Äôs a detailed real‚Äëestate‚Äëinvesting profile for Belvedere, a mature neighbourhood in northeast Edmonton:

1. Nearby Amenities & Attractions

  • Transit: Belvedere LRT station (Capital Line) with large park-and-ride (‚âà780 stalls) provides strong transit connectivity (nexthome.ca, Wikipedia).
  • Shopping: Londonderry Mall is just northwest at 137‚ÄØAve &‚ÄØ66‚ÄØSt in Kildare (Wikipedia). Commercial corridors along Fort Road and 66‚ÄØSt include retail and services (belvederecl.com).
  • Recreation & Landmarks: Community league facilities (hall, outdoor rink), plus historic Transit Hotel and a prominent brick smokestack visible from LRT (Wikipedia).

2. Housing Age & Common Types

  • Most construction occurred between 1946 and 1985, with over 90% of residences built in that era (Wikipedia).

  • Breakdown of dwelling types (approximate):

    • Apartments/low‚Äërise: ~45%
    • Single-family houses: ~42%
    • Duplexes: ~8%
    • Row houses: ~6% (Wikipedia).

3. Zoning & Density Potential

  • Located in a mature area sector, zoning is mostly traditional residential (R‚Äëclass). Edmonton zoning does permit secondary suites, duplex, row‚Äëhouse, and some multi‚Äëunit conversions depending on lot size and local overlays. You would need to consult the city‚Äôs current zoning map for Belvedere under the Mature Area Overlay to confirm allowable density including multiplex or low-rise multi‚Äëunit. (Typical RPL, RSL, or RMD zones may allow more units per lot with design and lot‚Äësize compliance.)

4. Population & Growth

  • In 2012, population was around 5,085 over 1.67‚ÄØkm¬≤ (‚âà3,045 people/km¬≤) and had grown about 2.2% since 2009 (Wikipedia).
  • More recent figures (AreaVibes): population ~5,805, median age ~37.8, livability score 69/100 (good) (AreaVibes). Indicative modest slow growth.

5. Income Levels

  • From 2001‚Äì2010 era data, median household income $48,600; average ~$56,800‚Äîwell below the city average ($72,000 median, ~$90,000 average) (City of Edmonton, nexthome.ca).
  • Local Logic more recent estimate: individual income ~$37,200, family income ~$69,800 (Local Logic).

6. Crime Rate

  • Crime rates are significantly high: total crime ~108% above national average; violent crime ~62% above national average. Residents face a 1‚Äëin‚Äë12 chance of becoming a victim. Crime is about 38% above Edmonton average (AreaVibes).

7. Rental Supply & Demand

  • Approximately half of households rent (~48‚Äì50%) and half own (~50%) (Wikipedia, AreaVibes).
  • As of early August 2025, ~23 active rental listings, median rent ~$1,335/month, up almost 8% year‚Äëover‚Äëyear (Zumper - Apartments for Rent & Houses).
  • Rental stock appears stable with moderate demand, but supply is not extremely tight.

8. Average Rents

  • Median rental rate in Belvedere: ~$1,335/month for apartments of all sizes (Zumper - Apartments for Rent & Houses).
  • Approx breakdown: average 1‚Äëbedroom ~$1,119; 2‚Äëbedroom ~$1,528; studios ~$1,019 (Zumper - Apartments for Rent & Houses).
  • City-wide Edmonton averages range ~$1,365 to $1,520/month depending on source (Apartments.com, Zumper - Apartments for Rent & Houses).

9. Neighborhood Quality Classification

  • By standard real‚Äëestate grading (A = upscale/low‚Äëcrime to D = disadvantaged/high risk): Belvedere would align closer to C or D, reflecting lower incomes, elevated crime rates, older stock, and mixed ownership/rental status.

10. Home Prices & Appreciation Potential

  • As of mid‚Äë2025:

    • Listings average pricing ~$150‚Äì180‚ÄØK (per listings), price per sqft ~$179‚Äì286 depending on data source (edmontonrealestate.ca, HonestDoor).
    • HonestDoor reports average sale price ~$366,800; sold price per sqft ~$286 (HonestDoor).
    • AreaVibes median for Edmonton is ~$370K, while Belvedere likely below that (AreaVibes).

  • Returns/Cashflow: average rents ($1,335) vs property cost ($180‚Äì370‚ÄØK) suggests gross rental yield ~4‚Äë8%, modest cashflow depending on financing and expenses.

Long‚Äëterm potential:

  • Proximity to LRT and mature area redevelopment could support value appreciation. However, elevated crime and lower income limit demand from owner‚Äëoccupiers. Appreciation upside may hinge on targeted improvement, infill redevelopment, or converting low‚Äërise to multiplex units.

11. Investment Strategies That Could Work

  1. Small multi‚Äësuite income properties: Acquire older homes and add secondary suites (permitted) to boost yield.
  2. Low‚Äërise redevelopment or multiplex builds: Under R‚Äëzoning if permitted, subdividing or building duplex/triplex can increase units.
  3. Buy-and-hold rental: Affordable entry point, stable rental demand; focus on landlords comfortable managing older stock.
  4. Value-add flips or renovations: Improve curb appeal, safety, rentability to attract better tenants or resale buyers.
  5. Transit-oriented rental strategy: Marketing to students and commuters using LRT access.

Recommendations

Kildare

Here‚Äôs a detailed outline and analysis of Kildare, a mature northeast Edmonton neighbourhood in the Londonderry area:

1. Nearby Amenities & Attractions üè¨

  • Londonderry Mall sits within Kildare at 66‚ÄØStreet & 137‚Äì144‚ÄØAvenue, offering major retail, services & dining (Wikipedia).
  • Londonderry Athletic Grounds, with sports fields, running track & fitness centre, lie adjacent and serve the community broadly (Wikipedia).
  • Parks within Kildare include Kildare Park and Cherrydale Park, which feature playgrounds, fields and gathering spaces (Wikipedia).
  • Nearby transit access is solid, supporting walkability, biking and transit commutes (Local Logic).

2. When were houses commonly built?

  • Majority of residential development occurred in the 1960s through the 1980s/early 1990s (City of Edmonton).

3. Common Building Types

  • Around 60% are single-detached homes. The remaining ~40% comprises row houses, low-rise apartments and duplexes (Gimme-Shelter).

4. Zoning Regulations & Unit Multiplicity

  • Edmonton‚Äôs Zoning‚ÄØBylaw‚ÄØ20001 (effective Jan‚ÄØ1,‚ÄØ2024) introduces the RS Zone allowing up to 8 dwelling units per lot by default depending on lot area and configuration (Storeys).
  • Under the RS Zone, a minimum 225‚ÄØm¬≤ lot supports at least 3 units; a 600‚ÄØm¬≤ lot allows up to 8 units including basement suites, row housing or multiplexes (Situate Inc.).
  • Proposed council debate (June‚ÄØ2025) aims to possibly reduce the maximum to 6 units per mid‚Äëblock lot, but as of now the eight-unit cap is still in effect (Taproot Edmonton).

5. Population & Growth

  • In 2012, the population was 2,763 living in 1,209 dwellings, a ‚Äì4.3% decline since 2009 (Wikipedia).
  • More recent growth: the greater Londonderry area (Kildare‚ÄØ+‚ÄØKilkenny) may have seen modest recovery; Kildare is not listed as high‚Äëgrowth.
  • HonestDoor reports +7.14% average price growth year-over-year (likely correlated to modest demand) but not direct population growth data (Wikipedia, HonestDoor).

6. Average Household Income

  • Specific Kildare income stats unavailable; neighboring York had average household income around $53,200 (2001) vs Edmonton average $57,360 at that time (Wikipedia).
  • Given demographic similarities, Kildare income is likely at or slightly below Edmonton average.

7. Crime Rate

  • Kildare‚Äôs crime rate is reported as approximately 93% higher than the Canadian average, with violent crime around 50% above average, and a 1-in-13 chance of victimization. It‚Äôs safer than only ~24% of Alberta neighbourhoods (AreaVibes).

8. Rental Supply & Demand

  • Rental turnover is moderate: about 40% renter-occupied units in community (Gimme-Shelter).
  • Some townhomes and apartments available: only around 1‚Äì2 current rentals online in Kildare specifically, showing limited supply and stable demand (Zillow).

9. Average Rents

  • A current townhouse rental for 2‚ÄØbed / 2‚ÄØbath was listed at approximately C$1,365/mo (Zillow).
  • Other listings in surrounding areas ranged C$1,200‚Äì1,900‚ÄØper month depending on bedroom count.

10. Neighborhood Grade (A/B/C/D)

  • Kildare is a mature, working-to-middle income community with aging stock, moderate income and elevated crime.
  • It likely falls into a ‚ÄúC‚Äù grade neighborhood, with some potential upside but also limitations.

11. Long-term Appreciation vs Cash‚ÄëFlow

  • The average property price is around C$269,000 (HonestDoor), with listed active homes averaging C$310,000, and an average of C$279/sqft (HonestDoor, AreaVibes, Reddit, edmontonrealestate.ca).
  • Year-over-year growth ~7‚ÄØ% indicates modest appreciation. With average rents at approx $1,400/month, gross rents are about <‚ÄØ6% yield on typical prices‚Äîthin positive cash flow.
  • Appreciation appears stronger than cash flow, making it more drift toward value-growth/revitalization play, not high-yield.

12. Average House Prices

  • HonestDoor average property price: ~C$269,210 (HonestDoor).
  • Current active listings average: ~C$309,800 (range $130k to $450k) (Wahi).

13. Investment Strategies That Could Work

  • Missing‚ÄëMiddle Infill Strategy: Given RS zoning allows 3‚Äì8 units per lot, a duplex or row‚Äëhouse infill with secondary suites could boost net operating income.
  • Renovation & Hold: Purchase older single-detached homes at lower cost, renovate and hold for moderate rent and capital growth.
  • Condoconversion: As some multiplexes can be condominiumized over time, converting to condos could allow resale exit strategies (Storeys, Reddit).
  • Buy & Rent to Own/GRSP: Mid‚Äëmarket affordability attracts renter‚Äëfamilies; offering rent‚Äëto‚Äëown may attract stable tenants.
  • Focus on turn‚Äëkey row‚Äëhouse units for reliable tenancy and tighter maintenance.
